qas.question: Where does the name Rhine derive from?
What is the French name for the Rhine?
What is the Proto-Germanic adaptation of the name of the Rhine?
What century did the name of the Rhine come from?
What does the name The Rhine come from?
What is the Rhine called in French?
What is the Proto-Germanic adoption of the Gaulish name of the Rhine?
What is the Rhine called in Dutch?
How was the Dutch name for the Rhine originally spelled?
Where are the variant forms of the name of the Rhine in ancient languages derived from?
What century did the Germanic vocalism Rin come from?
What century did the spelling with Rh- in English Rhine come from?
What century did the French adopt the Germanic vocalism Rin-?

context: The variant forms of the name of the Rhine in modern languages are all derived from <a0_2><a4_2>the <a0_0><a4_0><b9_0>Gaulish name <a0_1><a0_3><a0_4><a4_4>Rēnos<b9_0/><a4_4/><a4_2/><a4_0/><a0_4/><a0_3/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>, which was adapted in <a3_2>Roman-era<a3_2/> geography (<a3_0><a3_1><a3_3><a4_3><b10_0><b11_0><b12_0>1st<a3_1/> century BC<b12_0/><b11_0/><b10_0/><a4_3/><a3_3/><a3_0/>) as Greek Ῥῆνος (Rhēnos), Latin <a4_1>Rhenus<a4_1/>.[note 3] The spelling with Rh- in English Rhine as well as in German Rhein and French <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><a1_3><a1_4><a5_0><a5_1><a5_2><a5_3><a5_4>Rhin<a5_4/><a5_3/><a5_2/><a5_1/><a5_0/><a1_4/><a1_3/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/> is due to the influence of Greek orthography, while the vocalisation -i- is due to the Proto-Germanic adoption of the Gaulish name as <a2_2>*<a2_0><a2_1><a2_3><a2_4><a6_0><a6_1><a6_2><a6_3><a6_4>Rīnaz<a6_4/><a6_3/><a6_2/><a6_1/><a6_0/><a2_4/><a2_3/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>, via Old Frankish giving Old English Rín, Old High German Rīn, Dutch <a7_0><a7_1><a7_2><a7_3><a7_4>Rijn<a7_4/><a7_3/><a7_2/><a7_1/><a7_0/> (formerly also spelled <a8_0><a8_1><a8_2><a8_3><a8_4>Rhijn<a8_4/><a8_3/><a8_2/><a8_1/><a8_0/>)). The diphthong in modern German Rhein (also adopted in Romansh Rein, Rain) is a Central German development of the early modern period, the Alemannic name Rī(n) retaining the older vocalism,[note 4] as does Ripuarian Rhing, while Palatine has diphthongized Rhei, Rhoi. Spanish is with French in adopting the Germanic vocalism Rin-, while Italian, Occitan and Portuguese retain the Latin Ren-.
